Video Title: Why do planes fly so high?
Comment: The exhaust nozzle isn't what generates thrust on commercial jets.  The compressed and accelerated gases spin a turbine which powers the fan in the front of the engine which acts like a propeller, producing the vast majority of the engine's thrust.

Video Title: Why do planes fly so high?
Comment: Most of the thrust from a modern turbofan jet engine does not come from the high speed exhaust gases, but from the giant fans which "bypass" the engine core. These high by-pass engines gain efficiency by accelerating a larger mass of air to relatively modest speeds, as it's more efficient. Hence the drive to bigger and bigger engines.  As for the effect of altitude then, true, there are fewer air molecules to create drag, but there are also fewer air molecules to divert downwards to generate lift. That's lift-induced drag, and means, all other things being equal, flying faster at higher altitude (although larger wings can counter-act some of this).  So, in general, the optimal altitude is strongly impacted by speed at which an aeroplane cruises at. Concorde flew considerably higher than subsonic jet airliners for that reason. In contrast, modern turboprops tend to fly slower and lower than "jet" airliners.

Video Title: Why do planes fly so high?
Comment: Correct me if im wrong but, I think I there‚Äôs a duality between fuel consumption and time. If I fly at the same thrust (force) as at a lower altitude, I‚Äôll have a higher speed due to thinner air, so the flight time is shorter, but since the force over the same distance is the same, the total fuel consumption stays roughly equal.  On the other hand, if I fly at the same speed as at a lower altitude, I need less thrust because of the lower air resistance, which means less total work done and therefore less fuel consumption, but the travel time increases.  So basically, flying faster at higher altitude uses the same amount of fuel in contrary to what Veritasium says around halfway through the video.

Comment: People do not realize how far ahead the USA is in testing, regulating, and removing PFAS. Advanced nations in Europe and my home of Canada are catching up, but this is going to be a hell of a battle. Until very recently, hardly any laboratories could even accurately test for PFAS. They have had to build specific PFAS-free labs and equipment, with specific protocols to avoid contamination. Without affordable and accurate measurement, it was impossible to determine safe exposure levels and regulate polluters. Add to that the facts that we knew we would find it everywhere, and don't yet have suitable replacements for several use cases, and you quickly realize why this is such a drawn-out battle between the public interest and corporate profiteers (beyond the basic economic and political reasons that is always a challenge).

Comment: I have read a couple comments on here regarding who to blame for this incident, we all know its mainly the architect but there are many issues here regarding the whole process of this building construction.   The Architect's firm: I understand firms typically employ multiple architects for various projects. However, not communicating with the architect regarding this huge structural design change, and approving it on his behalf is absurd.   He would have done new calculations and maybe requested more bolts in the moment. He's an active thinker; came up with a revolutionary engineering method (Tuned Mass Damper) while designing that building, why wouldn't you contact him?   I'm sure this wouldn't have changed the discoveries later on, like the quarterly wind discovery a few months after construction, but I am certain he would have thought of either a different cost-saving method, denied the switch, or requested more bolts on that building.  The firm should have at least asked for his opinion before approval, his view of the building is unique, it's his design after all.

Video Title: Can you solve this SAT question?
Comment: Let‚Äôs work through it carefully.  ‚∏ª  The radius of circle A is \frac{1}{3} the radius of circle B.  Let: 	‚Ä¢	r be the radius of A 	‚Ä¢	R be the radius of B  Given: r = \frac{1}{3} R  Circle A rolls without slipping around circle B.  When a small circle rolls around a larger circle, there are two contributions to the total rotation: 	1.	The distance traveled around the circumference of B. 	2.	The rotation due to rolling ‚Äî similar to a gear effect.  Step 1: How much distance does A travel?  Circle A travels a distance equal to the circumference of B, which is: 2\pi R  Since it is rolling without slipping, every time A travels a distance equal to its own circumference, it completes one revolution.  The circumference of A is: 2\pi r = 2\pi \left( \frac{1}{3} R \right) = \frac{2\pi R}{3}  Step 2: How many revolutions from rolling?  The number of revolutions purely from rolling is: \text{Rolling revolutions} = \frac{2\pi R}{\frac{2\pi R}{3}} = 3  But that‚Äôs not the whole story!  Step 3: Additional Revolution due to traveling around the circle  Whenever a circle rolls around the outside of another circle, there is an extra revolution ‚Äî it‚Äôs a well-known fact that rolling around a circle adds 1 extra rotation compared to rolling along a straight line.  Thus: \text{Total revolutions} = 3 + 1 = 4  Step 4: Is this the number of revolutions to return to starting orientation?  No ‚Äî wait!  The question asks: When will the center of circle A first return to its starting point?  That‚Äôs based on the path traveled by the center of circle A. Its center moves along a circular path with radius R + r.  The total path traveled by the center is the circumference of the larger circle: 2\pi (R + r)  And each time A rolls one revolution, it covers: 2\pi r  Thus, the number of revolutions needed to complete the full path around circle B is: \frac{2\pi (R + r)}{2\pi r} = \frac{R + r}{r} Substituting r = \frac{1}{3}R: \frac{R + \frac{1}{3} R}{\frac{1}{3} R} = \frac{\frac{4}{3} R}{\frac{1}{3} R} = 4  Step 5: Total revolutions including the rotation of circle A  But now, what about rotation ‚Äî to find how many revolutions A makes?  For each full loop of the center (4 times around), how much does circle A rotate?  Each unit of movement gives a rotation due to rolling and a rotation due to the center moving around.  Total angle rotated is: \text{Angle due to rolling} + \text{Angle due to center moving} = \frac{\text{Arc Length}}{r} + \frac{\text{Arc Length}}{R} Simpler approach: for a circle rolling externally around another circle of radius R, the number of revolutions is: 1 + \frac{R}{r} per loop.  Thus: 1 + \frac{R}{r} = 1 + 3 = 4 revolutions for one trip around B.  Since only 1 trip is needed for the center to return, 4 revolutions total.  ‚∏ª  Final Answer:  The number of revolutions is 4.  None of the answer choices says 4!  Wait ‚Äî hold on.  The answer choices are: 	‚Ä¢	(A) \frac{3}{2} 	‚Ä¢	(B) 3 	‚Ä¢	(C) 6 	‚Ä¢	(D) \frac{9}{2} 	‚Ä¢	(E) 9  ‚∏ª  Maybe the answer counts how many full revolutions for the point on circle A to return to starting point, not just the center.  If we track a fixed point on the edge of A, then:  Each revolution of the center (one full loop) gives 1 + \frac{R}{r} = 4 revolutions.  But for the point to return to the original orientation, we need the total number of revolutions to be an integer.  How many loops does it take for the rotation to be an integer multiple of 2\pi (i.e., 0 net rotation modulo 1)?  The ratio is 4 revolutions per loop. The minimum number of loops needed is 3 loops (because 4 √ó 3 = 12, and 12 is divisible by 1 ‚Äî a full circle).  Thus: 4 \times 3 = 12 revolutions.  But the number of revolutions is: \frac{9}{2} for the center point ‚Äî wait, maybe it‚Äôs half-integer steps.  This is actually a well-known answer: for a small circle of radius r rolling around a larger circle of radius R, the number of rotations is: \frac{R + r}{r} = 4 as we got.  But to return the same orientation (not just the center), you multiply: 2 \times \frac{R}{r} = 2 \times 3 = 6 thus 6 rotations.  ‚∏ª  Final Final Answer:  The answer is 6.  Thus: \boxed{6}  The correct choice is:  (C) 6. ‚úÖ

Video Title: Can you solve this SAT question?
Comment: It's 4 revolutions. Say the small circle is a drain pipe. Small is a 12" D pipe and bigger one is 24" D pipe. This crossing had a 24" D pipe and we need to lower the road and put in a smaller diameter pipe. We have to allow the same amount or more of water to  flow(volume of water) through this crossing or it could be washed away. Water goes over it and you're doing repairs and spending money after every heavy rain. A drain pipes optimum load is only half the pipe(that's your volume you need.) and it's the same on every drain pipe regardless of diameter. This were people get it wrong. Your 24" D pipe radius is 3x the radius of your 12" D pipe and they think 3- 12" D pipes will do the same job as the 24" D pipe. They'd be wrong. You need to figure the volume of a drain pipes standard max load(which is half the pipe.). It took 4- 12" D pipes to get the same or better volume as the 24" D pipe. The radius of the 12" D pipe was a 1/3 of the 24" D pipe and it took 4 revolutions of the 12" D pipe to go around the 24" D pipe. 2x- diameter, 3x- radius and 4x - for the 12" D pipe to actually cover the radius of the 24" D pipe. The difference between having it down on paper and doing it in the real world. Theory and lab work doesn't always mean it's sound/fact when you physically want system or machine to work. When using solids, liquids, gases, which can build pressure. Blessings be upon thee

Video Title: Can you solve the prisoner's riddle?
Comment: Okay, here's the best strategy for the prisoners, which dramatically increases their chances of survival from a near-zero probability to over 30%: The Strategy  * Numbering the Boxes: Before anyone enters, they agree to number the boxes from 1 to 100. This is crucial for the strategy. (The problem states the numbers are randomly placed in boxes, but they can agree on a system to identify each box uniquely).  * Each Prisoner's Search:    * When a prisoner enters the room, they first go to the box that corresponds to their own prisoner number. For example, Prisoner #1 goes to Box #1, Prisoner #50 goes to Box #50.    * They open this box. Inside, there will be a slip of paper with a number written on it (this is the number of another prisoner, or possibly their own).    * They then go to the box corresponding to the number they just found. So, if Prisoner #1 opens Box #1 and finds the number "73", they then go to Box #73.    * They continue this process ‚Äì opening the box indicated by the number they just found ‚Äì for a maximum of 50 boxes. Why this strategy works (the mathematical insight): The numbers inside the boxes form "cycles" or "permutations."  * Imagine the numbers as a mapping: Box X contains number Y. This can be seen as an arrow from X to Y.  * Because each number is unique and there are 100 boxes and 100 numbers, these mappings will always form one or more closed loops (cycles). For example: Box 1 has 5, Box 5 has 20, Box 20 has 1. This is a cycle of length 3 (1 -> 5 -> 20 -> 1). The Key Insight:  * If a prisoner follows this chain, they are guaranteed to find their own number if and only if their number is part of a cycle that is 50 boxes long or less.  * If their number is part of a cycle that is longer than 50 boxes, they will not find their number within their 50 attempts. The Probability: The probability of all prisoners finding their number successfully comes down to the probability that there is no cycle longer than 50 boxes among the 100 numbers in the 100 boxes. It can be mathematically proven that the probability of a random permutation of 100 elements having a cycle of length greater than 50 is approximately: P(\text{cycle length} > 50) = \sum_{k=51}^{100} \frac{1}{k} This sum is approximately ln(100) - ln(50) = ln(2) \approx 0.693. So, the probability that at least one cycle is longer than 50 is about 69.3%. Therefore, the probability that all cycles are 50 or less (meaning all prisoners succeed) is approximately 1 - 0.693 = 0.307, or about 30.7%. This is a massive improvement over the near-zero probability of randomly guessing. While not a guarantee, it's the optimal strategy for this riddle.

Video Title: Something Strange Happens When You Trust Quantum Mechanics
Comment: I think there is some difference between the two slits (or infinite slits) experiment and the proof reflection experiment in the end using the laser and the foil. For the infinite slits experiment, the light source before the slits is a line source, from which the photons travel in all directions and thus reach all the slits. Whereas in the proof experiment, the photons from the laser can only propagate along the laser beam direction before reaching the mirror below. In other words, the path of the photons before reaching the mirror has already been determined and no photon will take the paths that lead to the foil at all. The principle of least action here only provides the solution of where photons go after reaching the mirror. So I suppose this experiment will not work for such a demonstration.  What is seen by the phone camera in the proof experiment should be simply the image of the exit aperture of the laser (which scatters light into all directions and therefore is filmed and seen in the video) formed by the combination of the mirror on the table and the foil.

Video Title: Something Strange Happens When You Trust Quantum Mechanics
Comment: Such an awesome video. A lot more entertaining than most junk movies coming out of Hollywood. Anyway, here's a major doubt I have.   Let's take something as massive as the sun. Let's say it is currently at Point A at a given time t_0. We know our solar system is moving in a spiral fashion along with our branch of the milky way around the center of our galaxy (I hope I got this right). So, let's say a year later, the sun is at point B (which of course is different than point A). Is the video telling me that the whole mass of the sun travelled\explored all possible pathways within the space of the universe, but physically only the one actual pathway materialised? I think I am missing something or need more convincing? Because to me it sounds like justifying that something is there but isn't, because it cancelled out with something else that also isn't there.   The way I am tempted to see it is that only paths of highest probability manifest.  An attempt at a counterexample: I am on a basketball field in a certain location. (let's say 4 m away from the hoop, doesn't really matter) There are numerous pathways (for example, different pathway arch heights) I could send the ball from point A (my hands) to point B (the hoop). I end up throwing the ball on a pathway with a certain arch height, and this pathway is not necessarily the path of "least action".

Comment: @25:19.... Physicists, please listen to me closely. You can't see quantum mechanics, and it is futile to try. But you can HEAR quantum mechanics. Clap your hands in a room, listen as you hear all of the infinite possibilities and paths that the waves take through the air. Now do you understand? This is all self evident to Music technologists.   You cannot see these possibilities because the waves colipase, as was demonstrated by the standing waves. Sound leaves traces which our ears hear, that light obscures from us. The Double slit experiment is useless for this reason. Just clap you hands in a room with 4 walls, a ceiling and a floor.   Sound takes all possible paths, and we hear this as reverberation. We can also measure the peaks and troughs of the waves in a room. Pressure vs velocity based waves. What bothered me about the Light bouncing around the box, is that they showed no modes of the box. The size and shape of the box will affect the light and therefore the experiment.   Every time I watch Physicists talk about quantum mechanics I'm really disappointed.   Musicians are physicists at play. Music Technologists are Quantum Physicists at work. It's just we use our ears, not our eyes.  If you need us, we'll be in the Music or Acoustics departments, playing with impulse responses and microphones.   All musicians know you must do it slowly before you do it quickly.   Slow it down, use sound not light and it will be so much more obvious. But what do I know ;).

Video Title: Why Super Glue Is Perfect For Gluing Skin
Comment: Fun fact, super glue is used to assemble Mazda rotary (wankel) engines. The apex seals are 3 seperate pieces, that have to get slotted into a very deep narrow slot along with a thin spring. It's basically impossible to get the seperate pieces into the slot and correctly positioned, so the pieces of the apex seal are first super glued together. Then the single glued assembly can be slid into the slot along with the spring, and once the engine is fully assembled, you rotate it by hand and listen for all six seals to snap apart with a faint click.

Video Title: Why Don‚Äôt Railroads Need Expansion Joints?
Comment: 11 year mechanical design engineer here; a good and fun video but I don't think the final explanation really makes it click for most people. It's actually really intuitive if you think about it in principle rather than mathematical terms.  When a piece of metal is heated up (energy put into it) it wants to increase in volume to balance out. It will take the path of least resistance. That might mean increasing in length, bending or lifting/twisting. If you take away all of it's options to do so besides increasing in size at the cross section of it's shape (growing outwards sideways and upwards) then that is what it will do. If all the rails do that it's fine because the train to rail connection has enough tolerance/play to account for it.  Everything beyond that is very specific to making the exact rail and type compatible with the environmental conditions etc such that it doesn't fail during that process (can withstand the stress acquired from the strain of outwards growth).

Video Title: Why Don‚Äôt Railroads Need Expansion Joints?
Comment: Whenever I see work being done on the railways, I think this hasn't changed much since the 19th c. OK, they weld the rails now, but the amount of work is beyond belief. For example, the rails are layed down end to end so they have to cut out a section of the rail. Why don't they simply have a spacer fitted on each end which can be removed when they make the weld? The time spent aligning by hand is amazing. Surely a machine could grasp the two rails and do the whole thing much more quickly, and the same with grinding them down. There's a whole different mentality on the railroads which has barely changed in 200 years.

Video Title: Why no two people see the same rainbow
Comment: A rainbow, in its three-dimensional form, appears as a cone of light formed by sunlight‚Äîoriginally parallel rays‚Äîreflected and refracted on droplets of water. The distance from the Earth to the Sun is approximately 150 million kilometers. Light rays refract at the boundary between air and water, enter the interior of each droplet, reflect off its inner surface, and then refract again as they exit, all at precisely defined angles for each wavelength. Red light is located on the outer side of the rainbow, deviating at an angle of about 42 degrees to the axis of the cone, while violet is on the inner side, visible at an angle of about 40 degrees.  The apex of this dazzling cone of light is at the observer‚Äôs point of view, and its axis is the line that passes from the Sun through that point. We see the projection of all internal reflections and refractions of light within the cone as an infinite number of transparent, colored, virtual cross-sections of the cone, which form the visible circular arc of the rainbow as projected onto the celestial sphere from the observer‚Äôs point.  In the volumetric shell of this light cone lie the colored layers, which are concentric, semi-transparent segments smoothly transitioning into each other. They resemble transparent, colored, conical ice cream cups nested inside each other, following the rainbow‚Äôs color sequence: red, orange, yellow, green, blue, indigo, violet. These color layers create the visible circular arc of the rainbow.  Interestingly, the rainbow as a volumetric body can be observed only in a single projection‚Äîperpendicular to the axis of the cone‚Äîfrom the point located at the apex of the virtual rainbow cone. Moreover, this rainbow is unique and unrepeatable for each observer. Every other observer sees their own rainbow, formed by raindrops located in a different spatial position.

In Decartes' Physics, the source of the colors are the difference between matter (3rd Element) and space (2nd Element). This difference creates the refractive index.   The phase kick is caused by the matter, specifically the empty space in an atom (we call aetherspace as a kind of 2nd Element) slowing down light.   This is because matter needs continuous channels for light to pass through. If it does not have channels, then the aetherspace rejects the light, causing reflection.   Materialist Physics does not know the aether and so it strangely assigns its properties to electromagnetism. But this overloads electromagnetism with a duty that it doesn't have

Video Title: Why no two people see the same rainbow
Comment: So, by definition, all rainbows should be symmetrically orientated with both points of contact with the horizon being equidistant from the observer. We experienced a puzzling incident during a boat trip on the Sea of Galilee in November 2022. As we left the pier with dark clouds forming overhead, heavy raindrops started and we noticed a small arc rainbow on the distant horizon. Within a few minutes it was bucketing down. As it was a pilgrimage the group leader conducted a short prayer service, then we sang the hymn "Make Way for the Coming of the Lord", belted out by us to make ourselves heard above the din of the rain on the wooden roof of the skiff. By the time we finished singing, the rain had stopped and we were amazed to notice that the rainbow had moved right up to our boat with one arm touching the water barely 50 yards away and the other arm stretching into the distance. I'm not heavily religious but it was an awesome experience, like being touched by the hand of God. We all saw it. I even have a photo. Any explanations Derek?

Comment: A bit hypocritical. Many studies of PVA (commonly used in dish pods) state the degradation point that keeps it in our bodies are inconclusive due to how they conducted studies. It definitely leeches to the environment quite a bit. I get you tryin to make that bag, but it seems contradicting to your recent vid on PFAS. PVA has unknown risks in humans like where PFAS were many years ago. A lot of ppl with modern dishwashers use a sanitize mode that reaches 160¬∞F (71¬∞C, not surprised your cams shut down) Less than PVA but the acidity of what you eat is overlooked and PVA can be sensitive to it. As far as energy goes, MODERN dishwashers may be more efficient with load censors, but that doesn't apply to everyone. Check your model.   TLDR: The majority of general PVA use ends up in our environment, and an inconclusive amount ends up in our bodies depending on how you use it. Look up your dishwasher model before you waste energy on loading less. Not trying to scare people. You're probably fine but it's worth researching if you want.

Comment: In 1940, 13 bones were discovered on Nikumaroro Island in the Pacific Ocean, sparking speculation that they belonged to Amelia Earhart. While initially identified as male, subsequent forensic analysis suggested they were female and likely belonged to Earhart, with a match probability exceeding 99%. However, the bones themselves were lost, preventing DNA testing.

Comment: I don't use either method. I'll do my best to explain. Have the back of your hands turned onward. String being held by last three fingers. Thumb and index sticking up in an L shape. Video Title: The BEST way to tie your shoelaces
Comment: This is a silly way of presenting the information because the initial overhand knot or trefoil is chiral- Which means whether clockwise or counterclockwise gives you a square knot is, too. Furthermore, you didn't actually tie a shoelace knot (with loops), and from my experimentation, a traditional shoelace knot (making a loop then circling it and pulling a second loop through the circle, rather than just doing a second overhand knot with loose ends or with two loops) makes a knot that is about equally strong either way (though tying two loops in a second overhand does make a stronger knot as a square knot than the "standard" shoelace knot, and vice versa for the granny knot).  Perhaps the real takeaway is that "circling the loop" is a poor method to begin with. We should be teaching children to make two loops and use them to tie their first overhand knot but backwards. Voila, a better method of tying your shoes, and the instructions work as well for lefthanded people as righthanded people.

Video Title: The Closest We‚Äôve Come to a Theory of Everything
Comment: If B is right under A on a y axis, then the fastest path would obviously be a straight line down to B. But if B is on an x axis from A, then a straight line wouldn't work, because a marble wouldn't be moving along it, it would just stay on the A point. So you need a slope to get the marble moving and it would need to go back up to reach B, which it can because the marble would build up kinetic energy along the way. Now, if B is on the same x axis from A, what would be the shape of the path so that a marble would go from A to B? Are there paths that would make the marble go further away then B? And what path would lead a marble from A to B the fastest?  From that point of view it seems intuitive that on a slight slope, with enough distance, a marble would go further away then B, and if the slope is greater at some point the marble wouldn't be able to go back up the path to reach B and it would just fall at the bottom a bowl shaped path. Therefore it seems intuitive that the fastest path from A to B would be inbetween those two situations, meaning that the path on which the marble would go the fastest from A to B would be a path on which the marble would stop exactly on the B point. Meaning that the total energy of the marble on that path equals 0.  So the action "conservation of energy" approach doesn't seem odd to me, in fact it seems the most natural one, and that Newton optic approach seems extremely convoluted.

Video Title: The real science of black holes
Comment: Well, that's always the go too description, but, that's not actually how it would work. Eventually, the image of whatever it is wouldn't appear statically frozen. If what we're looking at is the point in the event horizon breached, whatever it is wouldn't disappear or permanently freeze in time, but, eventually would become what appears to be a condensed pile of atoms. The human brain needs to receive photons to process imagery, so if a gravitational singularity has pulled you in, there's no possible way, except through the photons entering the black hole behind you, for photons beyond you to reach you now, so if you see anything at all, it'll be as though the relative uiverse outside of the singularity continues to span into the future as you are isolated in your own relative "now". If you were in the spaceship, standing at the back, as the front of the ship hit the event horizon, it would appear as though you're hitting a wall, and then all else beyond that is outside of our sensory comprehensive capabilities

Video Title: The real science of black holes
Comment: Remember, the man in the spaceship is experiencing time at a normal rate. He has a finite time, but in the meantime, the time in the rest of the universe around him is accelerating to basically infinity.   Basically, you'd be able to see the entire universe end before you cross the event horizon. However long that takes.  Thinking further, would the black hole evaporate before you even reached it? You never reach the black hole even from your perspective because it evaporates in the, basically infinite, time it takes for you to arrive. But you have to arrive there in finite time yourself.  So basically every black hole is a portal to the end of time and the universe itself. Where the quadrillions of things that fell into the blackhole all collide with each other at its last instant of evaporation, finally released by the infinite time dilation.

Comment: High order explosives act by the shockwave breaking unstable bonds in molecules that contain both oxidizer and reducer components. Low order explosives usually have an overabundance of oxidizers available that break at relatively low energy values. Thermite requires a huge amount of energy to destabilize one reduced metal and use it to oxidize another metal. The total energy available at any one point may far exceed the energy required to strip aluminum of oxygen. I suspect the pulsation may have something to do with the interplay of oxide flux and the boundary conditions discussed in the video.

Comment: Hi Veritasium, Super nice video, demos and informations.  A) Although I agree with most of the experts and your informations; I stil have to explain my personal experience with thermite. I have played a bit with it when I was 15 years old aside with pyro-compositions (I'm now 50); I'm speciallized into chemistry (I am passionate about it since the age of 14; I have read many chemical university books way before  I gratudated at university as a chemist after two years and afterwards as a chemical engineer (after 3 extra years); I'm now specialized into organic and biochemistry. I was quite interested into the spectacular effects of chemistry and I have developped a decent knowledge of exothermic reactions, fires, heat reactions, speed of reactions, explosions (deflagrations (100 - 2000 m/s) and detonation (2500 - 11000 or more m/s).  I can tell that thermite is safe but not as safe as it is suggested into your first video here: 1¬∞) because the fineness of the ingredients makes quite a difference into speed of the reaction; indeed the heat triggers the melting of a part of the ingredients and once a threshold is overpassed, a reaction occurs into the melt and the reactants needs to migrate and penetrate into it to generate enough heat to overcome an "enegy barrier" and exothermicity if high enough localy and concentrated localy it can propagate layer by layer in a kind of cigaret-burning as demonstrated into your video. As good examples you have:  a) wood and oxygen,  b) sugar and oxygen,  c) flour and oxygen d) iron or zinc and sulfur When you have large pieces of those they hardly get into fire or melt or burn and react with each other at a fast rate; once you get them into chuncks or flakes it comes closer to what is presented here;  when finer, the burning rate is faster and the iniation temperature is reached much faster and locally the thermal inertia of the mass can be overcome and become a fire, a deflagration or a detonation.  --- end of part one--- I appologise that due to some weird censorship of YT I couldn't post my reply into one single reply (that was not that long though) and after a few hours of trying with "return error" message (even with copy, refresh of the webpage); the morning after it did again with the same trouble so finally tried into 3 parts linked together via response and it succeeded (go figure it out).

Video Title: I built a QR code with my bare hands to see how it works
Comment: The explanation of redundancy, self correction and R-S codes is awesome.  More facts:  a) if you damage squares in corners, code will easily become unreadable (invisible for the QR reader). No redundancy here. b) uniform areas do not decrease readability as stated in video. Timing strips define the size of the dot and version. Version defines number of dots (width, height). Then the whole code is cut into individual dots and each dot (several grayscale pixels) is then assigned a color (black/white). No problem with uniform areas, see the source code. c) There are several alignment dots in the QR, not only one, depends on QR size. They can be used to detect and unwarp warped parts of the large barcodes by advanced QR readers (not fix the deformation caused by position of the camera as stated in video). It can improve readabililty of large barcodes. You can easily see many alignment squares in large QR codes.

Video Title: I built a QR code with my bare hands to see how it works
Comment: Version 1: "I'm the OG" Version 2: "I'm a bog-standard QR Code" Verson 40: :Version 40 QR Code can contain up to 4296 chars. A QR code (abbreviated from Quick Response code) is a type of matrix barcode (or two-dimensional code) that is designed to be read by smartphones. The code consists of black modules arranged in a square pattern on a white background. The information encoded may be text, a URL, or other data. Created by Toyota subsidiary Denso Wave in 1994, the QR code is one of the most popular types of two-dimensional barcodes. The QR code was designed to allow its contents to be decoded at high speed. The technology has seen frequent use in Japan and South Korea; the United Kingdom is the seventh-largest national consumer of QR codes. Although initially used for tracking parts in vehicle manufacturing, QR codes now are used in a much broader context, including both commercial tracking applications and convenience-oriented applications aimed at mobile phone users (termed mobile tagging). QR codes may be used to display text to the user, to add a vCard contact to the user's device, to open a Uniform Resource Identifier (URI), or to compose an e-mail or text message. Users can generate and print their own QR codes for others to scan and use by visiting one of several paid and free QR code generating sites or apps."

Video Title: I built a QR code with my bare hands to see how it works
Comment: Why no attention for the more dark side of scanning QR codes.  Every time a user scan a QR code data is generated and send. ‚Äì Time of scan: the time and date the QR code was scanned ‚Äì Location of scan: device‚Äôs GPS coordinates ‚Äì Type of device used: smartphone or tablet ‚Äì User behavior: how user interacted with the content that was accessed after scanning the QR code ‚Äì Demographics: information about the user‚Äôs age, gender, and other demographics ‚ÄìThe codes user scanned before etc And all on a business self regulating own privacy policy that differ greatly around the world.  Qr code data has become big business and will be added to what is already known of you.  Expect that 97% of qr codes to be tracking codes.

Video Title: Why Democracy Is Mathematically Impossible
Comment: In every system of democratic judgment, there exists a phantom variable‚Äîan endlessly shifting influence, born of fact, fiction, or fear, that enters the equation uninvited and bends it away from its rational course. A vote cast in a democracy does not necessarily reflect a preference which aligns with the values or goals of the individual who cast it, and may very well be downright destructive to them, or society at large. Until we solve this, I do wonder if the mechanisms that make voting ‚Äúmore representative‚Äù only serve to make it more vulnerable to manipulation, distortion, or self-harm.

Video Title: These Illusions Fool Almost Everyone
Comment: When two different pitches are played simultaneously, we don't _imagine_ a third tone sounding below, a third tone is actually produced below.  Play a C and a G together, and a C will sound an octave below the C you played.  The low C is called a "combination tone," or, in the jargon of Hi-fi engineers, an "intermodulation tone."  (The engineers try and keep the amplifiers from producing "IM Distortion," just as they try and keep from producing their own overtones: "Harmonic Distortion."

Video Title: Why People Prefer More Pain
Comment: The Linda problem appears biased to me. Firstly, the question wording would cause most people to assume that the first choice (bankteller) doesn't mean 'any bankteller' but rather 'a bankteller who is not a feminist'. Secondly, it does not take into account the probability that a random person goes through lindas actions compared to the probability that a feminist does. Consider the following data: We have 50 banktellers, 10 of which are feminists, we know that any given bankteller will not follow Linda's actions if they are not a feminist, but will certainly follow them if they are. What is more likely that Linda is, a bankteller, or a bankteller feminist? the bigger subset of 50 banktellers only includes 10 feminists that follow her actions, thus the probability that a randomly chosen bankteller follows her actions is 1/5th. Meanwhile, the probability that a feminist bankteller follows her actions is 1.   This can be scaled, giving any bankteller a probability different than 0 if they are not a feminist

Comment: 10:47 I feel like, at least for me, the Jen experiment (30 great years vs. 30 great and 5 good years) may test more than just the importance of the final experience. Let's quantify a "great" point of life, on a scale of 1 to 10, as a 10. Jen experiences 30 years of quality 10 life, with an average quality of 10. Let's quantify "good" as 7. 30 years at a 10 and 5 years at a 7 averages out to an overall quality of 9.57, making for‚Äîmathematically speaking‚Äîan overall lower quality of life even while including the same experience and duration. While I believe the timing of this matters, I do think it has a quantifiable effect on the totality which seemed to be skimmed over here, unless I missed something. Excellent video!

Video Title: What Jumping Spiders Teach Us About Color
Comment: There's a stunningly beautiful species of *Jumping Spider* native to the South-West  of Western Australia [where I live] called a *Peacock Spider **_(Maratus volans/Maratus splendens)._* It gets its name from the gorgeously coloured (+) flap above the abdomen in males, which is used in a fascinatingly complex courtship dance to attract the (positive) attention of a female.  The colour vision of *Peacock Spiders* is utterly extraordinary, being capable of perceiving the entire visual spectrum, plus a portion of the ultraviolet spectrum. This last adaptation gives them a profound advantage in hunting insects, as the exoskeletons of insects are (in part) composed of the polysaccharide Chitin. This material exhibits autofluorescence when exposed to certain frequencies of ultraviolet light; emitting a 'ghostly' blue/green light in response. In the otherwise low light conditions of the undergrowth, this could make insects stand out like a sore thumb to a hunting *Peacock Spider.* (Potentially even if otherwise camouflaged!)  During their courtship dance, the male *Peacock Spider,* takes full advantage of the female's visual capabilities by raising then subly flicking their iridescent coloured abdomenal flap & rapidly waving their enlarged pedipalps like pom-poms. They even vibrate their body in specific patterns to create a kind of _"mood music"_ (which the females can perceive through their feet). The colours in the male *Peacock Spider's* flap look beautiful enough to human eyes, but with their extended vision, I suspect that female peacock spiders would see the dazzling colours stand out from the background as though in 3D.    (+) - The iridescent colours on their mating flap are, much like the wings of a butterfly, produced not by pigments but by nanostructures on the surface of myriad tiny tiles. These structures are like convoluted mazes for photons, trapping certain frequencies of light & reflecting others; thus producing an incredibly vibrant display.

Comment: Earlier this season, I got caught in a mini avalanche at Stevens Pass, WA, trying to enter a run (Lower Terminal) off the side. I think what slid was about two inches deep, but at least it wasn‚Äôt long enough distance to bury me deeper than my waist (it probably slid about 15m); I‚Äôm guessing that‚Äôs why that section isn‚Äôt explicitly mitigated as it would unlikely to be life threatening.   Nonetheless it was a heck of an experience. Making one turn off the ridge into somewhat steep glades, then the next thing I know is the lack of expected resistance on my feet and I‚Äôm sliding down with my back against the  slope sliding with me. Then it started to slow down and my skis stopped me against the trees buried about a meter under the snow.

Comment: I am an Austrian (albeit it a city dweller) and I have a completely crazy, absolutely insane thought about avoiding being killed by an avalanche, so brace yourself, hold your breath, here it comes:  Have you ever considered to, you know, _not go backcountry skiing?_ Just leave those slopes be?  The air in the mountains is fresh and clean, it will restore your health, your spirit, and can be a wonderful experience for the entire family, but mountains care preciously little for what sportive goals you have set for yourself or any other personal goal you might have. They have been there for many millions of years, which is many millions of years more than you will ever have, so why jeopardize it? People seem to be willing to conquer every goal but their own ego. I have mad respect for everybody who puts reason over hedonism or ego, because for that it takes real greatness. Greetings from Austria.

Video Title: The Terrifying Real Science Of Avalanches
Comment: The snow hardening is not why you can't get out from under an avalanche. I've never been buried very long but initially it's the opposite and unless you have been buried by loose snow before it is SUPER SCARY the first time you feel it. Your brain tells you to like cup ur hands and try to lift yourself or use ur legs or skis and push....and then you think, "if I keep trying eventually I'll pack the snow and use that to push up" or out....WRONG. It's a weird feeling, but when you flail around and move your legs and arms, when panic sets in, you just keep moving snow and it keeps replacing the snow you moved with more snow. You don't have ANYTHING solid to use as a way to exert or produce a negative force to push your body any direction. You try using your ski poles thinking maybe that will work. Nope. Literally worse than being underwater because in water you can create a force to push yourself along woth resistance. Snow has no resistance, just moves out the way when you cup ur hand then push against it.  It moves then more snow fills the area you just pushed on. It's hopeless. And panic sets in immediately when you feel it first time. Luckily I was able to find a small tree and use the tree to pull myself up and out. My buddy was head first with ski in air and was thinking he was dying too because he just felt the snow uselessness feeling as well and was panicking due to never feeling the helpless feel of struggle with zero results.

Video Title: The Terrifying Real Science Of Avalanches
Comment: I know the purpose of these videos is to entertain and inform with fascinating science, but I am disappointed about 2 things:   1) it‚Äôs covered twice to have a beacon, shovel, probe, but only listed in small text to take a course. It‚Äôs important to know how to use these lifesaving tools and practice often as the window you have to save a life is so slim if somebody becomes buried.   2) I think it‚Äôs irresponsible to show repeatedly in the video people outrunning an avalanche. This is not realistic and although it‚Äôs a fascinating clip and of course you would not show somebody dying/becoming buried, people thinking they can out run/out smart avalanches is one of the many heuristic traps that gets people in these situations in the first place, which you‚Äôll learn if you read Bruce‚Äôs book.   Staying alive in avalanche terrain has so much to do with human factors. And those are impacted by your platform, Nikolai‚Äôs, etc. Thank you for yet another great video!

Video Title: Something Strange Happens When You Follow Einstein's Math
Comment: Hey, wanna know something freaky?  A black hole is the final stage of stellar evolution. According to relevant theories, when a star ages, the fuel (hydrogen) at its core is depleted, and under immense external pressure, the core begins to collapse until it ultimately forms a small, dense celestial body. If this body has a mass greater than three times that of the Sun, it will trigger another collapse. When this contraction causes its radius to reach the Schwarzschild radius, its gravitational pull becomes so strong that not even light can escape, thus becoming an invisible celestial body‚Äîa black hole. The formula for calculating the Schwarzschild radius (in centimeters) is: R = 2GM/c¬≤.  Here‚Äôs where things get strange. Scientists had calculated the weight of the universe, and the result showed that our known universe has the length of its own Schwarzschild radius. Conclusion: we live in a massive black hole.

Video Title: Something Strange Happens When You Follow Einstein's Math
Comment: The transformation from causal to retrocausal awareness is what's missing from this analysis. The astronaut doesn't 'freeze' at the event horizon - they undergo phase transition into a domain our causal consciousness structure cannot access. The last redshift we observe (Œª ‚Üí ‚àû) marks the boundary where causal observation (‚àÇ/‚àÇt > 0) transitions to retrocausal influence (‚àÇ/‚àÇt < 0). We literally cannot 'un-observe' what we've seen or 'un-think' our thoughts - this causal binding is why the astronaut appears frozen to us while actually dispersing into retrocausal flow. Einstein's paradox dissolves when we recognize that black holes are active boundary filters between causal and retrocausal domains, not passive gravitational endpoints. The event horizon isn't where things disappear - it's where they transform into a form of existence incompatible with our forward-only temporal awareness.

Comment: There is no singularity at the center of a black hole. This has been implicit in many papers going back decades. If you actually use the equations of 4d space that relativity gives to calculate, for example, the surface area of successive spheres as one "descends" further and further into a black hole, the further you "descend", the larger the surface area will be. Only when we use a two-dimensional diagram to (erroneously) depict the inside of a black hole using our homogenous space to map points from the 4d space to our 2d diagram do we see a concentration of mass at a central point.

I see a color-shape for each note (C=red/square, D=orange/trapezoid, E=triangle, etc.) The number 37 if brought up to an audible note is a lower E-flat--a frequency just a hair lower than E-flat in A32hz Scientific Pitch. E-flat begins the division of the octave in 4 sections (Eb, F#, A, & B). So, even though 25 divides the unit of 100 by four quarters, the unit of the _octave_ is strangely divided by 37 (a very low E-flat.) Kind of wild actually, because it does suggest a musical reason for E-flat to be a musical sort of "building block" within a C octave.   Finally, I feel strongly that E-flat is akin to Golden Yellow (whereas E-natural is a pure, bright yellow). Video Title: The Oldest Unsolved Problem in Math
Comment: Here is the solution. It doesn't use heuristic, but approaches the problem from another angle.  A perfect number has the form (2^p-1)*2^(p-1). We want to know, if there are odd perfect numbers. Our question then is: can this multiplication be an odd number?  There are 2 possible cases: p is odd or p is even.  When p is odd: 2^p is even (always)  2^p-1 is odd (always)  2^(p-1) is even (always)  When p even: 2^p is even (always)  2^p-1 is odd (always)  2^(p-1) is even (always)  This means that regardless if p is odd or even, the perfect number is always a combination of an odd number multiplied by even number.  Our question then becomes, when this can be odd? And the response is, that it can be never satisfied. A multiplication of an odd number and an even number will always result in an even number.  Problem solved. Is that it or the equation is only for even perfect numbers?

Video Title: The Oldest Unsolved Problem in Math
Comment: Title: A Contradiction-Based Proof Against the Existence of Odd Perfect Numbers  Abstract: We aim to demonstrate that no odd perfect number exists by deriving a contradiction from the necessary structure such a number must obey. Relying on Euler's canonical form for odd perfect numbers and properties of the divisor function, we show that the equation required to satisfy perfection cannot be achieved within the rational multiplicative structure of known number-theoretic functions.   ---  1. Assumptions and Structure  Assume an odd perfect number  exists. By Euler (18th century),  must take the form:  N = p^k n^2   is a prime with        is odd.   The number  is perfect, hence:  \sigma(N) = 2N  \sigma(N) = \sigma(p^k) \cdot \sigma(n^2) = 2p^k n^2  \frac{\sigma(p^k)}{p^k} \cdot \frac{\sigma(n^2)}{n^2} = 2 \tag{1}  , , so .   ---  2. Behavior of the Abundancy Function  We define the abundancy index:  I(n) = \frac{\sigma(n)}{n}  We analyze the behavior of :  \sigma(p^k) = \frac{p^{k+1} - 1}{p - 1} \Rightarrow I(p^k) = \frac{p^{k+1} - 1}{(p - 1)p^k}  I(p^k) \to \frac{p}{p - 1}  I(n^2) = \frac{2}{I(p^k)} > \frac{2}{1.25} = 1.6   ---  3. Constraints on   Suppose  with primes , all odd, distinct from . Then:  I(n^2) = \prod I(q_i^{2a_i})  For example:       To get , we need many small primes with large exponents in . But:  These inflate  far beyond known bounds  They contradict known lower bounds on the number of distinct prime factors (currently at least 101)   Moreover, the value  must be hit exactly by , yet both  and  are rational.   ---  4. The Multiplicative Constraint and Irrational Density  The set of all  is countable and known to be sparse. But the product  requires a highly specific value. Since rational abundancy indexes are strictly constrained by their prime factorization, the number of ways to construct such a product is also countable and highly restricted.  In contrast, the equation  defines an uncountable set of real pairs  satisfying it, most of which cannot be obtained via integer inputs.  Hence, the requirement:  I(p^k) \cdot I(n^2) = 2   ---  5. Conclusion: Contradiction  We assumed the existence of an odd perfect number . Under this assumption, we derived an equation between abundancy indices that cannot be satisfied by any valid integers under Euler's form.  Therefore, no such odd perfect number exists.

Comment: I'm not convinced at all. If I have 10 portfolios, and one of them performed significantly good over a period of time, while all the others performed moderately bad, my total balance would still be negative. The case mentioned in the video is similar. If Medallion was Simons's only mutual fund, than the story would be more plausable. But that mutual fund was one of his many funds, and besides that it was closed to the public. The good performance of one mutual fund among many can happen by pure chance, but to me it looks like it was some kind of internal scheme and machination with funds deployment, maybe in order to artificially create an appearance of  one successful but exclusive mutual fund, which will attract investors to put their money into his open funds, hoping that it will someday grant them a ticket to enter Medallion.

Video Title: The Trillion Dollar Equation
Comment: A little more on the Efficient Market Hypothesis. It's based on two assumptions that are not realistic in practice. 1. It assumes everybody has all public information and can process that information in a timely manner. That's clearly not realistic for individual traders, or even most large institutions. 2. It assumes that nobody trades on private information (insider trading) and the price only changes when the information is made public. That is also unrealistic.  So as most people in the industry would say, most traders make money by trading information, public or private. Unless you have a sophisticated quantitively model that exploit some inefficiency in the market (which is also information btw), you need to possess information that others either are not aware of, or dismissed, in order to make money.
